'''Mason Ruffner''' (born 1953)<ref name="Review">{{cite web|url=http://www.masonruffner.com/Discography/Reviews/reviews-gypsy.htm |title=Gypsy Blood |publisher=Masonruffner.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> is an American [[blues]] and [[rock music|rock]] singer, guitarist and songwriter.  He has worked with many musicians including [[Bob Dylan]], [[Daniel Lanois]], [[Robert Ealey]], [[Memphis Slim]], [[John Lee Hooker]], [[Jimmy Page]] and [[Ringo Starr]].<ref name="AMG">{{cite web|last=Seida |first=Linda |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mason-ruffner-mn0000318132 |title=Mason Ruffner - Music Biography, Credits and Discography |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> From 1985 to the present, Ruffner has released six albums, including ''Gypsy Blood'' (1987) and ''You Can't Win'' (1999).<ref name="AMG"/> 

Ruffner's career has been inspired by [[Jimmy Reed]],<ref name="Burnside"/> [[Jimi Hendrix]], Bob Dylan, [[Lightnin' Hopkins]] and [[Howlin' Wolf]]. In addition, he has drawn influences from the literary work of the [[French people|French]] poets, [[Comte de Lautréamont]], [[Charles Baudelaire]] and [[Arthur Rimbaud]].<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Last">{{cite web|url=http://www.last.fm/music/Mason+Ruffner/+wiki |title=Mason Ruffner’s Biography|publisher=Last.fm |date=2013-01-15 |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref>

==Life and career==
Ruffner was born in [[Forth Worth, Texas]], and grew up in a strict Protestant home.<ref name="AMG"/><ref name="Review"/> He initially relocated to California at the age of 17, but returned to Texas in the 1970s inspired to play music.  His early musical experiences included playing at Fort Worth's Bluebird Lounge, playing alongside [[Robert Ealey]] in his backing ensemble known as the Five Careless Lovers.<ref name="Bio">{{cite web|url=http://www.masonruffner.com/Biography/Biography.htm |title=Biography |publisher=Masonruffner.com |date=2013-02-26 |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> Moving on again he arrived in [[New Orleans]] in the late 1970s,<ref name="Last"/> intending to travel across Europe.  However he was enchanted by the music he heard there, particularly work by [[Smiley Lewis]] and [[Huey "Piano" Smith]].<ref name="AMG"/>

Ruffner formed the Blue Rockers and found regular employment at Club 544.  There he backed visiting musicians such as [[John Lee Hooker]] and [[Memphis Slim]]. Spotted playing in 1985 by [[Sony Music Entertainment|CBS Records]]' [[Tony Martell]], Ruffner was offered a [[recording contract]] with the [[record label|label]].<ref name="Last"/> His debut album, ''Mason Ruffner'' (1985), was [[record producer|produced]] by [[Rick Derringer]],<ref name="allmusic1">{{cite web|last=Viglione |first=Joe |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/mason-ruffner-mw0001878649 |title=Mason Ruffner - Mason Ruffner : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> and earned critical acclaim from both ''[[Rolling Stone]]'' and ''[[The New York Times]]''. He went on to tour supporting [[Jimmy Page]]<ref name="AMG"/> and, in 1987, released ''Gypsy Blood'', which was produced by [[Dave Edmunds]].<ref>{{cite web|last=Gottlieb |first=Bob |url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/gypsy-blood-mw0000191695 |title=Gypsy Blood - Mason Ruffner : Songs, Reviews, Credits, Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> The album reached No. 80 in the [[Billboard 200]].<ref name="allmusic2">{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.allmusic.com/artist/mason-ruffner-mn0000318132/awards |title=Mason Ruffner - Awards |publisher=AllMusic |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> The single, "Gypsy Blood" peaked at No. 11 in the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Mainstream Rock Tracks]] [[record chart|chart]].<ref name="allmusic2"/>

His support work on tour at the back end of the 1980s included sharing the stage with Page again, plus later on with [[Crosby, Stills, Nash & Young|Crosby, Stills & Nash]], [[U2]] ([[The Joshua Tree Tour]]) and [[Ringo Starr]].<ref name="AMG"/> 

In 1989, Ruffner played on Dylan's ''[[Oh Mercy]]'' album, and [[Daniel Lanois]]' ''[[Acadie (album)|Acadie]]''.<ref name="AMG"/> After this time,  Ruffner bought a property in [[Wimberley, Texas]], and largely withdrew from the music limelight for almost a decade. He then moved to [[Memphis,  Tennessee]], and performed at [[B.B. King]]'s Blues Club.<ref name="Burnside"/> In 1997, Ruffner's third album, ''Evolution'', was released in Europe but not in his homeland.<ref name="Burnside">{{cite web|url=http://www.burnsiderecords.com/mason.html |title=Burnside Records |publisher=Burnside Records |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref>

In 1999, Ruffner issued ''You Can't Win'', which contained predominately self composed material.<ref name="allmusic1"/> The album was more blues orientated, and featured a [[horn section]] for the first time on Ruffner's work.<ref name="Burnside"/>

''Mason Ruffner Live'' and ''So Far'' were released via [[CD Baby]] in 2007 and 2008.<ref name="AMG"/>

==Credits==
Ruffner's co-written "Angel Love (Come for Me)" has been performed by [[Carlos Santana]], with whom Ruffner has made a number of live appearances.<ref name="Last"/> "Gypsy Blood", from Ruffner's album of the same name, was featured in the 1989 [[film]], ''[[Steel Magnolias]]''.<ref name="Bio"/> Ruffner's [[music video]] for his [[Single (music)|single]] "Dancin' On Top Of The World",<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.discogs.com/Mason-Ruffner-Dancin-On-Top-Of-The-World/release/3141166 |title=Mason Ruffner - Dancin' On Top Of The World (Vinyl) at Discogs |publisher=Discogs.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> depicted him at the [[World Trade Center]].<ref>{{cite web|author= |url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=13rUzo_I8q0 |title=Mason Ruffner - Dancin' On Top Of The World |publisher=YouTube |date= |accessdate=2013-03-28}}</ref> Ruffner had a credit on Dylan's album, ''[[The Bootleg Series Volumes 1–3 (Rare & Unreleased) 1961–1991]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/the-bootleg-series-vols-1-3-rare-unreleased-1961-1991-mw0000595183/credits |title=The Bootleg Series, Vols. 1-3 (Rare & Unreleased) 1961-1991 - Bob Dylan : Credits |publisher=AllMusic |date=1991-03-26 |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref> In 1984, Ruffner performed at the [[San Francisco Blues Festival]] and, in 1998, performed at the [[Notodden Blues Festival]]. He also appeared at the [[Sweden Rock Festival]] in 2011.

==Accolade and quotation==
In Bob Dylan's [[memoir]], ''[[Chronicles: Volume One]]'' (2004), Dylan noted "Ruffner played in Bourbon Street clubs like the Old Absinthe Bar. He was a regional star, had a high pompadour, a gold tooth smile with a tiny guitar inlaid. He had a few records out and some explosive licks with funky edges, rockabilly tremolo-influenced, wrote songs, too, said that he'd hung around libraries reading Rimbaud and Baudelaire to get his language down. He also told me that as a teenager he had played with Memphis Slim. I thought I had something in common with him there. I'd played with Big Joe Williams when I was coming up. Mason had some fine songs. One of them had the line, ''"You do good things for people and it just makes them bad."''  I would have thought about recording it if I didn't have my own originals."<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cdbaby.com/cd/masonruffner6 |title=Mason Ruffner | Mason Ruffner | CD Baby Music Store |publisher=Cdbaby.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-22}}</ref>

Quoted in ''[[The Dallas Morning News]]'' in 1986, Ruffner noted "You buy some dark sunglasses. Standing up front is a lot different to standing on the side, man. Believe me, there's a big difference".<ref name="Rave">{{cite book
